excerpt: Mountain in the center of the city with a church & shrine, popular with pilgrims & tourists.
detail_description: Monserrate, a mountain located in the center of Bogota, is a popular destination for both pilgrims and tourists. At 3,152 meters high, it offers stunning panoramic views of the capital city. The mountain is home to the Sanctuary of Monserrate and features expansive gardens perfect for leisurely strolls. Additionally, visitors can enjoy dining at exclusive restaurants offering local and international cuisine.
name: Monserrate

excerpt: La Candelaria is Bogota’s vibrant heart, with landmarks like the colonial-era cathedral and neoclassical Capitol flanking Bolivar Plaza. Narrow streets lined with shops selling emeralds and handicrafts lead to cultural hotspots like the Gold Museum, with pre-Columbian artifacts, and Museo Botero, showing international art in a colonial mansion. Casual eateries serve dishes like ajiaco (chicken and potato soup).
detail_description: La Candelaria, located in Bogota, is a historic and vibrant neighborhood known for its colonial-era cathedral, neoclassical Capitol, and Bolivar Plaza. The area features narrow streets with shops selling emeralds and handicrafts, as well as cultural hotspots like the Gold Museum and Museo Botero. This neighborhood is also home to various museums, theaters, universities, and historic libraries set against the backdrop of cobbled streets and Spanish colonial buildings.
name: La Candelaria

excerpt: Contemporary structure housing exhibits on pre-Columbian gold, ceramics & stones, with a cafe.
detail_description: The Gold Museum, located in the historic city center of Bogota, is a contemporary structure that houses an extensive collection of pre-Columbian gold, ceramics, and stones. It is home to over 34 thousand pieces made of gold and tumbaga, showcasing the art and goldsmithing used by various indigenous communities in Colombia.
name: Gold Museum
address: Cra. 6 #15-88, Santa Fé, Bogotá, Cundinamarca, Colombia

excerpt: Prominent museum in a colonial mansion featuring works by Fernando Botero & other global artists.
detail_description: The Botero Museum, located in a colonial mansion in the heart of Bogota's Historic Center, is a must-visit for art enthusiasts. The museum showcases an extensive collection of works by Colombian artist Fernando Botero, known for his larger-than-life art. Donated to the state by the artist himself, the museum maintains Botero's original arrangement from its inauguration in 2000.
name: Botero Museum

excerpt: Spacious city center surrounded by a cathedral & important buildings with notable architecture.
detail_description: Plaza de Bolívar is a historic city center in Bogota, Colombia, surrounded by significant buildings and notable architecture. The area offers a mix of old and new, with the Plaza once being a stage for bullfights but now juxtaposed with modern structures like the Palace of Justice and Lievano Palace. Visitors can explore nearby attractions such as the Metropolitan Cathedral Basilica of the Immaculate Conception and take part in graffiti tours led by individuals involved in the urban art scene.
name: Plaza de Bolívar

excerpt: Florentine Gothic Catholic temple from the early 20th century with a unique striped paint scheme.
detail_description: Santuario Nuestra Señora del Carmen is a captivating Catholic temple in Bogota, Colombia. This unique church, built in the early 20th century, showcases a striking Florentine Gothic style with influences from Byzantine and Arabic art. Its most distinctive feature is the red and white horizontal stripes adorning both its interior and exterior. The church stands as a proud testament to history, having undergone restoration due to pollution and humidity damage in the late 1980s.
name: Santuario Nuestra Señora del Carmen

excerpt: Trendy Usaquén is a foodie hotspot. Asian fusion eateries, upscale French bistros and mellow garden cafes cluster around Usaquén Park, the district’s focal point, while brewpubs and chic cocktail bars keep the scene buzzing until late. Crowds gather on Sundays for the Usaquén flea market, featuring street musicians, puppet shows, gourmet food stands and stalls selling handmade jewelry to local coffee beans.
detail_description: Usaquén, located in the north of Bogota, is a trendy neighborhood known for its vibrant food scene and lively atmosphere. The area is home to a variety of dining options, including Asian fusion restaurants, upscale French bistros, and charming garden cafes centered around Usaquén Park. In addition to its culinary offerings, Usaquén hosts a popular flea market on Sundays called Mercado de las Pulgas de Usaquen.
name: Usaquén

excerpt: Bustling weekly gathering of outdoor vendors selling arts, crafts, food & gifts, plus entertainment.
detail_description: The Usaquén Flea Market is a vibrant weekly event in Bogota, Colombia, where outdoor vendors gather to sell a variety of goods including arts, crafts, food, and gifts. The market takes place in the charming cobblestone streets of Usaquén and offers a diverse array of products from luxurious jewelry to artisanal handbags. Visitors can explore the colonial neighborhood while discovering unique handmade items and enjoying delicious fresh foods.
name: Usaquén Flea Market
address: Calle 119 Con Carrera 6a, Bogotá, Cundinamarca, Colombia

excerpt: Upmarket Chapinero features a mix of mountainside residential sections and commercial zones with glitzy malls. Fine-dining areas like Parque de la 93 and Zona G buzz in the evening, as do the glamorous clubs and bars of Zona Rosa. The Chapinero Central neighborhood also has a lively gay scene. Landmarks include El Chicó Museum, a colonial hacienda set in parkland, and 19th-century Our Lady of Lourdes Basilica.
detail_description: Chapinero is a vibrant district in Bogota, known for its mix of upscale residential areas and commercial zones. The neighborhood offers a variety of dining options, from fine-dining areas like Parque de la 93 and Zona G to the lively nightlife in Zona Rosa. Chapinero Central is also recognized for its vibrant gay scene. Visitors can explore landmarks such as El Chicó Museum and Our Lady of Lourdes Basilica.
name: Chapinero

excerpt: Large, busy city green space with a walking/biking path,  a lake for boating & a kids' playground.
detail_description: Simón Bolívar Park, also known as the lung of Bogota, is a sprawling green space that offers a variety of activities for visitors. With 113 hectares of land, the park features walking and biking paths, playgrounds for kids, and several lakes where you can go boating. It has been a venue for numerous events and has hosted famous artists and even two popes.
name: Parque Metropolitano Simón Bolívar
address: Av. Calle 53 Avenida La Esmeralda #s/n y, Bogotá, Cundinamarca, Colombia

detail_description: La Puerta Falsa Restaurant, a 200-year-old establishment located near Plaza de Bolivar, is a beloved spot for locals and visitors alike. This cozy cafe has been frequented by well-known figures such as writers, actors, and ex-presidents. The menu features traditional Bogotano home-cooked meals including Ajiaco and Chocolate Completo.
name: La Puerta Falsa Restaurant

detail_description: The Edificio Administrativo Museo del Oro in Colombia showcases the expertise of the country's indigenous people in working with gold and bronze. The museum displays a wide array of meticulously crafted jewelry, including earrings, nose plates, necklaces, breastplates, and small sculptures depicting animals. These artifacts offer a glimpse into the pre-colonial life in Colombia. It is an excellent place to immerse oneself in the history of Colombia and appreciate the intricate craftsmanship of its ancient inhabitants.
name: Edificio Administrativo Museo del Oro

excerpt: Opened in 1955, this 20-acre botanical park features a waterfall, a sun clock & numerous orchids.
detail_description: Established in 1955, the Jardín Botánico de Bogotá José Celestino Mutis is a sprawling 20-acre botanical park that serves as both a recreational space and a research center. It boasts an extensive collection of Colombian and Latin American flora, showcasing the diverse ecosystems found throughout Colombia, with a focus on Andean and Paramo ecosystems.
name: Jardín Botánico de Bogotá José Celestino Mutis

excerpt: The G in Zona G means "gourmet," neatly summing up this foodie destination peppered with many of Bogotá’s swankiest restaurants. The neighborhood’s gastronomic haunts include chic brunch venues and cafes, and spotlight cuisines from all over the world. Part of the popular, cosmopolitan Chapinero area, Zona G has several upmarket hotels. Hiking trails at the nearby Quebrada La Vieja attract nature lovers.
detail_description: Zona G, short for "gourmet," is a foodie's paradise located in the cosmopolitan Chapinero area of Bogotá. This neighborhood is home to some of the city's swankiest restaurants, offering a diverse range of cuisines from around the world. Additionally, Zona G features upmarket hotels and is close to hiking trails at Quebrada La Vieja for nature enthusiasts.
name: Zona G

excerpt: Large museum with 20,000+ artifacts from the 16th century to modern times, plus a restaurant & shop.
detail_description: The Museo Nacional de Colombia is a large museum housing over 20,000 artifacts dating from the 16th century to modern times. It offers a comprehensive insight into the diverse ethnic and cultural influences that have shaped Colombia's history. The museum boasts an impressive collection of pre-Columbian art showcasing the skill and creativity of indigenous peoples, as well as more recent works by renowned Colombian artists such as Fernando Botero and Alejandro Obregon.
name: Museo Nacional de Colombia

excerpt: This colonial-era house where Simon Bolivar's once lived has been restored as a museum on his life.
detail_description: Museo Quinta de Bolívar is a museum located in Bogota, Colombia, housed in the colonial-era residence where Simon Bolivar once lived. The museum offers visitors a chance to step back in time and experience life as it was during Bolivar's era. The house contains original furniture and items from that period, making it a place of great historical and national significance.
name: Museo Quinta de Bolívar

detail_description: Andrés Carne de Res is a legendary steakhouse in Bogota, Colombia, known for offering a unique Colombian experience. The restaurant is famous for its stellar empanadas and all-night, alcohol-fueled benders that create a fiesta atmosphere. With a 75-page menu featuring succulent steaks, arepas, and ceviche, diners can enjoy hearty Colombian cuisine.
name: Andrés Carne de Res Chía

detail_description: Zona Rosa 1.1, also known as Zona T due to its T-shape, is a lively district in Bogota where locals go to party. It is located in the El Retiro neighborhood and is considered the city's entertainment hub. The area boasts trendy nightclubs, live DJ venues, classy bars, and restaurants catering to various tastes. Zona Rosa offers a vibrant nightlife scene with hundreds of well-heeled residents enjoying late-night parties on weekends.
name: Zona Rosa 1.1

detail_description: Capital Graffiti Tours in Bogota offers a unique and immersive experience, taking visitors on a journey through the vibrant street art scene of the city. Led by passionate locals who are well-versed in the captivating creations, these tours provide insight into the history, culture, and politics depicted in the murals. The tour showcases powerful representations of Bogota's culture and struggles as portrayed by celebrated street artists. Visitors can expect an English-speaking guide with options for private tours in Spanish or German.
name: Capital Graffiti Tours
address: Cra. 6 #15-88, Santa Fé, Bogotá, Cundinamarca, Colombia

excerpt: Spacious city center surrounded by a cathedral & important buildings with notable architecture.
detail_description: Plaza Bolivar, located in Bogota, has been a focal point of religious and cultural activities for centuries. Initially serving as a temporary open-air cathedral upon the arrival of Spanish colonists in the 16th century, it has also hosted a livestock market and circus. During Christmas, the plaza is adorned with vibrant fairy lights, creating a festive atmosphere. Despite being crowded, visitors can enjoy the bustling ambiance while exploring street food vendors and souvenir shops.
name: Plaza de Bolívar

excerpt: Landmark 16th-century Catholic church with an ornate altar & elaborate religious artwork.
detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Bogotá, the Iglesia de San Francisco stands as a testament to the city's rich history and architectural beauty. Constructed between 1550 and 1567 by Franciscan monks, this remarkable Catholic church is not only the oldest surviving structure in Bogotá but also a stunning example of Moorish influence on colonial design.
name: Iglesia de San Francisco
address: Av Jiménez de Quesada #7-10, Bogotá, Colombia

excerpt: Large local farmer's market with an indoor hall selling fruit, vegetables, meat, fish & flowers.
detail_description: Paloquemao Fruit Market is a bustling local farmer's market featuring an indoor hall where visitors can find a wide variety of fresh produce, including fruits, vegetables, meat, fish, and flowers. The market offers an abundance of Colombian specialties such as the lulo, granadilla, and guanabana. Visitors can also indulge in local delicacies like tamal made from corn flour and stuffed with chicken, pork belly, rice and egg.
name: Paloquemao Fruit Market
address: Av. Ciudad de Lima #25-04, Bogotá, Colombia

excerpt: Scenic green space with benches & playgrounds, plus festivals & other special events.
detail_description: Parque de la 93 is a popular outdoor destination in Bogota, offering green spaces, playgrounds, and benches for visitors to enjoy. It's a great spot for families to explore and play together. The park features attractive landscapes with large trees and plenty of seating areas for relaxation. Located in the northern end of Chapinero, it's known for its upscale atmosphere and modern amenities.
name: Parque de la 93

excerpt: Pedestrianized zone with a trendy vibe, offering numerous boutiques, bars & restaurants.
detail_description: Zona T, also known as Zona Rosa, is a lively and trendy pedestrianized zone in Bogota. During the day, it's a fashionable shopping district with high-end stores and eclectic boutiques. At night, it transforms into a vibrant hub for entertainment and nightlife. The area boasts numerous bars, restaurants, and clubs that cater to different tastes.
name: Zona T

detail_description: Andres Carne de Res is a popular hotspot in Bogota that started as a restaurant but has evolved into an entertainment hub. It's known for its vibrant party atmosphere, making it the ultimate Colombian party experience.
name: Andres Carne de Res

detail_description: Ciclovia Boyaca between 170 and 134 is a popular cycling route in Bogota, Colombia. This scenic path spans between the 170th and 134th streets, offering cyclists a safe and enjoyable way to explore the city. The route is known for its well-maintained paths, beautiful greenery, and vibrant atmosphere. It provides a great opportunity for both locals and tourists to stay active while taking in the sights of Bogota.
name: Ciclovia boyaca entre la 170 y 134

excerpt: Neoclassical national theater building inaugurated in 1892 & hosting regular major performances.
detail_description: Teatro Colón Bogotá is a neoclassical national theater building that was inaugurated in 1892 and is considered one of the oldest opera houses in the Americas. The architecture, inspired by the Parisian Palais Garnier, showcases delicate ornamentation dominated by frescoes of the six Greek muses painted by Italian masters.
name: Teatro Colón Bogotá

excerpt: Bogotá is Colombia’s sprawling, high-altitude capital. La Candelaria, its cobblestoned center, features colonial-era landmarks like the neoclassical performance hall Teatro Colón and the 17th-century Iglesia de San Francisco. It's also home to popular museums including the Museo Botero, showcasing Fernando Botero's art, and the Museo del Oro, displaying pre-Columbian gold pieces.
detail_description: Bogotá, the sprawling capital of Colombia, is situated at a high altitude in the Andes. The city's cobblestoned center, La Candelaria, is rich with colonial-era landmarks such as the Teatro Colón and Iglesia de San Francisco. Visitors can explore renowned museums like the Museo Botero and Museo del Oro which showcase art and pre-Columbian gold pieces respectively. Additionally, Bogotá offers diverse dining experiences and cultural discoveries.
name: Bogotá

excerpt: Built in the 17th century, this former church is now a museum, its walls covered in paintings.
detail_description: Museo Santa Clara, originally built as a church in the 17th century, is now a museum showcasing an impressive collection of religious art. The interior is adorned with intricate gold decorations and over 140 Baroque paintings that cover the walls. This former place of worship has been transformed into a cultural gem, offering visitors a glimpse into Colombia's rich colonial history through its ornate and original architecture.
name: Museo Santa Clara

excerpt: Historic square featuring a modest fountain, colonial buildings, cafes, restaurants & more.
detail_description: Plazoleta Chorro de Quevedo, also known as Pueblito Rolo, is a historic square located in the highest part of Bogota's La Candelaria neighborhood. It is believed to be the site where the city was founded and features colonial buildings, cobblestone streets, and a modest fountain. The area is popular with street artists and college students, creating a lively atmosphere.
name: Plazoleta Chorro de Quevedo

detail_description: Prudencia, a beloved restaurant in Bogota's historic center La Candelaria, is the creation of owners Mario Rosero and Meghan Flanigan. The restaurant exudes love and dedication in every aspect, from its architecture blending local bamboo with recycled materials to its freshly baked wood-oven bread and homemade spice blends. The sunlit dining room, once a colonial-style home, offers a rustic ambiance filled with the aroma of baking bread.
name: Prudencia

excerpt: Unfussy venue where patrons can drink beer, eat local grub & play a classic disc-tossing game
detail_description: Club de Tejo 76 is a laid-back spot where visitors can enjoy cold beer, local food, and the traditional Colombian game of tejo. This ancient game involves throwing a puck at gunpowder targets, creating an explosive effect when hit. The club offers shortened lanes for beginners to practice on. While it's one of Bogota's well-known tejo bars, the best places are often recommended by locals. It's suggested to visit during weekdays or weekends for the most popular experience.
name: Club de Tejo 76

excerpt: This historic, presidential residence with stately architecture offers guided tours by appointment.
detail_description: Casa de Nariño, also known as Palacio de Nariño, is the official residence and primary workplace of the President of Colombia. This historic building, constructed in the neoclassical style in the 17th century, stands as a symbol of the country's executive power. It holds significant historical value and offers guided tours by appointment.
name: Casa de Nariño
address: Cra. 8 #7 - 26, La Candelaria, Bogotá, Cundinamarca, Colombia

excerpt: Energetic shopping complex featuring multiple stalls selling homewares, clothing, artwork & more.
detail_description: Pasaje Rivas, located in the historic La Candelaria district of Bogota, is a bustling marketplace with over 120 years of history. This labyrinthine complex is filled with narrow passageways and crooked corridors that house a variety of stalls selling everything from handmade furniture, clothing, and artwork to traditional Colombian ponchos and leather goods. Bargaining is acceptable here, adding to the authentic experience.
name: Pasaje Rivas

detail_description: El Dorado International Airport in Bogota, Colombia is a bustling hub that offers car rental services from trusted companies like Avis and Localiza. The airport boasts modern check-in areas and easy access to transportation options such as cabs and Ubers. Travelers have reported quick immigration processes both when leaving and entering the country. The airport's cleanliness, organization, and friendly staff contribute to its positive reputation among frequent travelers.
name: El Dorado International Airport

detail_description: Graffiti in Bogota is a vibrant expression of art by local graffiti artists, showcasing their emotions and creativity on the city streets. The well-crafted street art adds to the urban charm, making it an awesome place to visit for those interested in this form of artistic expression. However, some visitors have noted that the surroundings may not always be clean. Nevertheless, exploring the streets of Bogota offers a unique opportunity to witness impressive graffiti and immerse oneself in the local art scene.
name: Graffiti

detail_description: La Candelaria, also known as Candlemass, is a historic and well-known neighborhood in Bogota. It's home to significant landmarks like the Botero Museum and the Gabriel Garcia Marquez Cultural Center. The area boasts narrow colonial streets lined with traditional houses and buildings, offering a glimpse into its Spanish colonial past. La Candelaria has evolved into a bohemian hub and a popular residential area for expats.
name: La Candelaria

detail_description: Nacimiento Cascada la Chorrera is a hidden gem, often overlooked by tourists who flock to the more popular La Chorrera waterfall and Chicaque Natural Park. This relatively unexplored trail offers a wonderful experience for those seeking a quieter and less crowded adventure.
name: Nacimiento Cascada la Chorrera

excerpt: Built in the 17th century, this Catholic shrine sits on top of a hill, 3,152 m. above sea level.
detail_description: Monserrate Sanctuary, a Catholic shrine dating back to the 17th century, is perched on a hill 3,152 meters above sea level. Visitors can enjoy guided tours with bilingual experts who tailor the experience to their interests and needs. The sanctuary holds deep religious significance for pilgrims who make the journey as an act of devotion. While many come for the breathtaking panoramic views, others are drawn by the traditions preserved in and around the site that inspire holy pilgrimages throughout the year.
name: Monserrate Sanctuary

excerpt: Intricate cathedral started in 1807 during Spanish rule & completed after independence in 1823.
detail_description: Catedral Primada de Colombia, located in the heart of Bogota's La Candelaria neighborhood, is a significant religious and historical site. Construction began in 1807 during Spanish rule and was completed after Colombia gained independence in 1823. The cathedral stands on the same grounds as the first church of Bogota, dating back to 1539.
name: Catedral Primada de Colombia

detail_description: The Bogota Bike Tours offer an informative and immersive experience of the city, starting from La Candelaria. The tour takes you through the colonial district, where you can explore the cobblestone streets, colonial architecture, and vibrant street art. There are options for both group and private tours, with passionate guides who are dedicated to sharing their love for cycling and the city. The private tour includes a ride up Guadeloupe mountain for stunning views of the city and countryside.
name: Bogota Bike Tours
address: Cra. 3 #12-42, La Candelaria, Bogotá, Cundinamarca, Colombia

excerpt: Sprawling, gay-friendly nightspot with 13 themed rooms & separate dance floors, plus regular events.
detail_description: Theatron is a massive nightclub located in a converted movie theater, boasting 13 themed rooms and separate dance floors with music ranging from reggaeton to techno. It is known as the largest nightclub in Latin America, accommodating up to 5000 people. The venue caters to a diverse crowd, officially being a gay club but also attracting many straight visitors and tourists. One of its unique features is one women-only nightclub among the ten different clubs housed within the complex.
name: THEATRON

detail_description: Iglesia de Nuestra Señora de la Candelaria is a small yet impressive Catholic church in Bogota, dating back to 1686. It serves as the local church for La Candelaria and boasts warm yellow walls, Spanish colonial architecture, and a picturesque mountainous backdrop. The church features stunning frescos, altars, and side-altars for Eucharistic Adoration.
name: Iglesia de Nuestra Señora de la Candelaria

detail_description: If you're exploring Bogotá, a visit to the Palace Historical Museum of the National Police is a must. Nestled in the charming La Candelaria district, this museum showcases the rich history and evolution of Colombia's National Police within an impressive colonial building. Visitors can delve into fascinating exhibitions featuring artifacts and weapons that highlight the police force's role throughout Colombian history, including its involvement in armed conflicts.
name: Palace Historical Museum of the National Police

excerpt: Landmark skyscraper with many offices & an observation deck occasionally open to the public.
detail_description: Colpatria Tower is a prominent skyscraper located in Bogota, offering a mix of office spaces and an occasional open-to-the-public observation deck. Situated near the public transport hub at the intersection of 7th and 10th avenue, it provides urban views featuring popular landmarks such as Hotel Tequendama. Visitors can enjoy capturing the city's skyline from different angles due to the area's abundance of buildings.
name: Colpatria Tower

excerpt: Modern, indoor-outdoor cultural center with an auditorium, exhibition space, a bookstore & a cafe.
detail_description: Located in La Candelaria, the Centro Cultural Gabriel García Márquez is a modern cultural center that serves as a symbol of unity between nations. Named after Nobel laureate Gabriel García Márquez, this innovative center features an auditorium, exhibition space, bookstore, and café. Designed by renowned architect Rogelio Salmona, the building's unique design includes ramps and a rooftop terrace offering stunning views of the surrounding area. The center also houses a library and hosts art exhibitions and events.
name: Gabriel García Márquez Cultural Center

excerpt: Amusement park with high-speed roller coasters & go-karts, plus kiddie rides & family attractions.
detail_description: Salitre Mágico, located in the Ciudad Salitre neighborhood, is an amusement park offering 34 attractions for both kids and adults. From high-speed roller coasters to bumper cars and classic county fair games, there's something for everyone. The park also hosts shows for kids and an annual Horror Festival during October. With a variety of rides suitable for all ages, including thrilling roller coasters and gentle kiddie attractions, it's a perfect destination for family fun.
name: Salitre Mágico

excerpt: Small museum in a skyscraper offering raw emeralds on display & information on the gem's history.
detail_description: Nestled within a towering skyscraper in Bogotá, the International Emerald Museum is a gem lover's paradise that showcases Colombia's rich emerald heritage. As the leading producer of emeralds globally, Colombia offers visitors an insightful journey into the world of these stunning green stones. The museum features an impressive collection of raw and polished emeralds, allowing guests to admire some of the finest specimens up close. You can delve into the fascinating history and mining processes behind these precious gems while exploring life in Colombian emerald mines.
name: International Emerald Museum
address: Edificio Avianca, Cl. 16 #6-66 piso 23, Santa Fé, Bogotá, Cundinamarca, Colombia

excerpt: Easygoing eatery with a terrace & a trendy vibe serving innovative cuisine, plus cocktails.
detail_description: Mesa Franca is a laid-back restaurant with a trendy atmosphere and a terrace, offering innovative cuisine and cocktails. Chef Ivan Cadena, known for his time at Central, combines bistro cooking with local produce to create award-winning dishes. The restaurant's mixologist, Tom Hydzik, crafts experimental cocktails to complement the food. The sommelier, Maria Paula Amador, curates an impressive wine selection.
name: Mesa Franca
